awd_titl_txt: CAREER: High-efficiency Regenerative Solar Energy Storage by Photoelectrochemical Redox Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Objectives and Approaches - The objective of this research is to explore high-efficiency regenerative solar energy storage, by using photoelectrochemical redox reactions and advanced semiconductors. The approaches are to obtain key fabrication parameters of the doped highly active photocatalysts; to study photoelectrochemical stability, activity, and storage capacity and efficiency; to design and set up a photoelectrochemical continuous flow reactor and investigate continuous energy conversion efficiency and kinetics; and to conduct computational fluid dynamic simulation of the continuous reactor.

Intellectual merit - The proposed multidisciplinary research will resolve the three major challenges that have hindered the development of efficient solar energy storage in the past, i.e., active and stable materials, high-capacity energy medium, and reversible conversion kinetics. This project strives to establish a methodology for the systematic design and effective integration of high-efficiency regenerative solar energy storage, as an alternative to H2 production from water splitting. It can provide new perspectives that would elevate our understanding of the photocatalytic mechanisms, allowing us to effectively predict the photo-electrochemical functionality and stability of potential systems.

Broader impacts - Successful execution of the proposed research will have profound impacts on broad research areas such as solar power, renewable energy, energy storage & generation, and many other sustainable and energy research fields. The proposed research will transform solar energy storage with better efficiency, improved storage capacity, and easy scale-up capability. Educational program will be integrated into the multidisciplinary research, aiming to shift the paradigm from lecture-based single-discipline teaching to student-centric multidisciplinary learning.

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on the possibility using advanced photoelectrodes (nanostructured TiO2, WO3, dye sensitization, and different combinations) to convert solar energy into electricity and store it for later usage when the sun is not available. In this project, we focused on the following research tasks: 1) obtain key fabrication parameters of highly faceted photocatalysts; 2) study photoelectrochemical stability, activity, and storage capacity and efficiency of selected semiconductor and redox couples; 3) design and set up a photoelectrochemical continuous flow reactor and investigate continuous energy storage efficiency and kinetics; 4) conduct computational fluid dynamics simulation of the continuous reactor, understand photoelectrochemical limiting step, and 5) provide the knowledge for tuning photoelectrochemical properties of the photoanode.

As a result of the above work, we have now established a detailed understanding of solar energy storage using both photoactive materials and redox species. A number of important outcomes have resulted from this work. An all-vanadium and continuous-flow photoelectrochemical storage cell has been developed for the first time, which takes advantages of forced convective flow of electrolyte to enhance mass transport. The cell has been demonstrated to effectively extend charging depth (by 5x) and photocurrent in solar energy storage. Convective flow of electrolytes was revealed to prevent reactant depletion and enhance interfacial reactions rates, and high-kinetics vanadium redox to reduce charge recombination and depress side reactions. Taking advantage of the improved photocurrent and diminished charge transfer resistance, the all-vanadium continuous-flow storage cell was capable of producing ~20% gain in state of charge (SOC) under AM1.5 illumination for ca. 1.7 hours without any external bias. In addition, innovative methodologies to synthesize geometry-enhanced high-aspect-ratio TiO2 nanobelts (TNBs), to enhance efficient charge separation, by stirring-assisted hydrothermal synthesis has been developed. Increasing the stirring speed from 0 to 700 rpm enhanced the specific rate constant of methylene blue degradation three times. Besides, TiCl4 treatment to the high-aspect ratio TNBs achieved a 2.3-fold increase in photocurrent in the all-vanadium photoelectrochemcal storage cell. The incident photon-to-current efficiency (IPCE) measurement conducted on the all-vanadium photoelectrochemcal storage cell demonstrated a doubled IPCE at 350 nm in comparison to that of P25. Furthermore, a WO3/TiO2 hybrid photoelectrode for all-vanadium photoelectrochemical storage cell aiming to implement simultaneously photoelectrochemical solar energy conversion and storage was developed. It was discovered that the vanadium redox species, due to their fast electrochemical kinetics, not only enhance the photocurrents under illumination through formation of HxWO3, but also help release reversely stored electrons under dark. We also made substantial progress in complementing the experimental results by developing computational simulations to elevate our understanding on the fundamentals of solar energy storage.

In addition to the above scientific advances, this project directly enabled 8 undergraduate students and multiple graduate students to engage in hands-on research opportunities and gain valuable research experiences. Three doctoral dissertations and one master thesis have been produced from this project. This project fostered great opportunities for students to seek career opportunities in the area of renewable energy field in the state of Massachusetts and beyond.
